title: Infectious Diseases
description: Test your knowledge of infectious diseases throughout history!

questions.question: What pandemic killed an estimated 50-100 million people worldwide in 1918-1919?
questions.explanation: The 1918 Spanish Flu pandemic was one of the deadliest in history, infecting about one-third of the world's population and killing an estimated 50-100 million people.

questions.question: What insect is the primary carrier of malaria?
questions.explanation: Malaria is transmitted by infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. The disease is caused by Plasmodium parasites that infect and destroy red blood cells.

questions.question: The Black Death, which devastated Europe in the 14th century, was caused by what?
questions.explanation: The Black Death was caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, spread by fleas on rats. It killed an estimated 25-50 million Europeans between 1347 and 1351.

questions.question: Which disease was known as the 'White Plague' due to the pallor of its victims?
questions.explanation: Tuberculosis (TB) was called the 'White Plague' because of the extreme pallor of its sufferers. It was a leading cause of death in the 19th century.

questions.question: What type of pathogen causes influenza (the flu)?
questions.explanation: Influenza is caused by influenza viruses. There are four types: A, B, C, and D. Types A and B cause seasonal epidemics, while Type A can cause pandemics.

questions.question: What disease did John Snow trace to a contaminated water pump in London in 1854?
questions.explanation: John Snow identified a contaminated water pump on Broad Street as the source of a cholera outbreak, helping establish the waterborne theory of disease transmission.

questions.question: What is the name of the virus that causes AIDS?
questions.explanation: HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) causes AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome). It was first identified in 1983 and attacks the immune system's CD4 cells.

questions.question: Which disease, transmitted by the tsetse fly, is also known as 'sleeping sickness'?
questions.explanation: African trypanosomiasis, or sleeping sickness, is caused by Trypanosoma parasites transmitted by the tsetse fly. It disrupts the sleep cycle and can be fatal if untreated.

questions.question: What disease did the antibiotic penicillin first effectively treat?
questions.explanation: Penicillin was first used to treat bacterial infections, particularly staphylococcal and streptococcal infections. It saved countless lives during World War II.

questions.question: Rabies is transmitted to humans primarily through what?
questions.explanation: Rabies is transmitted through the bite of an infected animal, most commonly dogs, bats, and raccoons. The virus travels through the nervous system to the brain.

questions.question: What is the term for when enough people in a population are immune to a disease, protecting those who are not?
questions.explanation: Herd immunity occurs when a sufficient percentage of a population is immune to an infectious disease, either through vaccination or prior infection, reducing its spread to vulnerable individuals.

questions.question: Which tropical disease, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, causes severe joint pain and is called 'breakbone fever'?
questions.explanation: Dengue fever is called 'breakbone fever' due to the severe muscle and joint pain it causes. It is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and affects millions of people annually.

questions.question: What is the difference between an epidemic and a pandemic?
options: A pandemic spreads across multiple countries or continents
questions.explanation: An epidemic is a disease outbreak within a specific community or region, while a pandemic is an epidemic that has spread across multiple countries or continents.

questions.question: What disease, once called 'consumption,' was the leading cause of death in the 19th century?
questions.explanation: Tuberculosis was called 'consumption' because of how the disease seemed to consume its victims, causing weight loss and wasting. It killed one in four Europeans in the 19th century.

questions.question: What is antibiotic resistance?
options: When bacteria evolve to survive antibiotic treatment
When people are allergic to antibiotics
questions.explanation: Antibiotic resistance occurs when bacteria evolve to survive antibiotic treatment. Overuse and misuse of antibiotics accelerate this process, creating 'superbugs' that are difficult to treat.
